He said that more than 80% of the sanctions are related to Iran’s nuclear program and that these will be removed with the final implementation of the deal.

I'm downgrading my estimate based on the potential for the debate over Iran's advanced conventional missiles to escalate to sanctions that involve SWIFT.  See: Iran unveils ballistic missile depot. Tasnim News Agency aired footage of an IRGC underground ballistic missile depot on January 5. The footage featured images of Emad ballistic missiles, which are capable of delivering nuclear warheads, as well as Parliament Speaker Ali Larijani touring the base. Iran test-fired an Emad ballistic missile on October 11; a UN panel later determined the test to be a violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1929, which required  Iran to refrain from “undertaking any activity related to ballistic missiles capable of delivering nuclear weapons.” This footage marks the second underground missile base shown recently to the public after the IRGC aired footage of another base on October 14. 
Larijani pledged Parliament’s commitment to support the country’s missile program during his tour of the missile base. He reassured his domestic audiences that the Sixth Five-Year Economic Development Plan–a set of economic and social priorities designed to guide the annual budgets from 2016 to 2021—emphasizes funds for the missile program. (Tasnim News Agency) (ICANA)
Affirming forecast. Given that the U.S. missed its own deadline for announcing missile sanctions, it seems pretty likely that no one in Washington or elsewhere will stand in the way of this.

I put the base rate of compliance with international agreements as pretty high, 95%.  This is politically sensitive, though reducing the likelihood.  However, to overcome this would require one of two conditions: Iran to not comply and the EU to retaliate, or the US to decide to comply with the JCPOA.  
Iranian hardliners decide to hold back (overriding the Supreme Leader, 10%), they either declare this (low probablity-5%) or are detected (slightly higher-25%), EU retaliates (75%).  This = .09
US option: Republicans decide to block the agreement during election year (50%, some would like to, but this is risky in an election year), they are able to build a coalition strong enough to override Presidential veto (10%).  =5%.  This would require a lot of collective gumption and risk acceptance.
There is also a wild card option of something destabilizing the US-Iran-EU relationship.  This is a non-trivial chance given the general instability in the region (say Iranian-backed Shia militias unilaterally attack US bases in Baghdad for example). push this down to 85% overall 
Iran's shipment of their Uranium stocks to Russia increases the likelihood of overall compliance-push back up to 91%
Up from 95 for passage of time and indications that Implementation Day could come early in the first few months of 2016.

In 2012, US pushed 15 Iranian banks out of SWIFT system which banned the banks from electronically moving money; this had a major impact on export / import as well as SME companies in Iran.  Main sub-question:
1. Who has major interest in re-introducing SWIFT in Iran? What would have to happen for a stakeholder to oppose SWIFT ban to be lifted? 
1a. IRGC - likelihood of support 80%, weight in decision 15%
IRGC plays a major role in business in Iran, business units of IRGC own major stakes in Iranian companies which will be greatly impacted by SWIFT decision. Firstly, SWIFT will allow Iranian corporations to wire money internationally and thus have an access to international markets to buy export but mainly to import much needed technology, spare parts etc. One of the biggest benefactors will be from oil industry where IRGC plays a key role. Secondly, on the other hand SWIFT will make it easier for foreign companies to access Iranian market and therefore intensify competition in many monopolistic / oligopolistic industries in Iran, this can potentially harm economic interest of IRGC.
Conclusion: It seems that the economic interest for IRGC is more strong in introducing SWIFT in Iran. The likelihood that they will favor the decision is in my view more than 80%. The risk to the scenarios are: some strong fraction with IRGC will have significant interests in guarding monopolistic position and will initiate steps that can put the process in the danger 
1b. International companies - likelihood of support 100%, weight 50%
International companies have probably the strongest incentive to introduce SWIFT in the country as this is an essential step in re-enetring the market in Iran
1c. P 5+1 Governments likelihood of support 70%, weight 35%
US, UK, France, China, Russia plus Germany
Group 1 (France, Germany) - strong business interest, countries sent delegations right after the signature of the deal...eg. PSA (Peugeot) is already in the process of re-establishing its operations with Iranian conglomerate Khodro. These countries will easily sell this at home to its voters - SWIFT / Iranian market access can boost sales of French and German companies. France, Germany have skin in the game in case the deal does not work with Iran but much less than USA and UK
Likelihood of support 90%, weight 35%
Group 2 (Russia, China) - complicated group of countries, they want to do business with Iran but at the same time, the countries are already doing business in Iran. SWIFT will mean more competition for their companies 
Likelihood of support 45%, weight 20%
Group 3 ( US, UK) - US and UK companies want to definitely do a business with Iranian companies but the governments have not only economical interests but also can suffer a lot from potential failure of the deal. However, local companies that might be interested to do business in Iran will be lobbying the governments + selling SWIFT to voters might not be that touchy topic 
Likelihood of support 65%, weight 45% SUM point 1
likelihood 87%, weight 97% 2. What are the chances that international transaction can be carried out in a different way than via SWIFT?
In my view, it is very unlikely
likelihood 3%, weight 3% SUM point 2
likelihood 3%, weight 3% TOTAL: 84% likelihood of SWIFT re-introduction in Iran

http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/26/iran-banks-swift-idUSL8N12Q2BN20151026 "Oct 26 Most Iranian banks will be able to reconnect to the SWIFT financial-transactions system . . . once Iran's nuclear-related measures have been verified, SWIFT said on Monday.
. . . .
"The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is expected to announce sometime in coming months whether it has verified Iran's implementation of the nuclear-related measures. "The European Union approved legislation on Oct. 18 allowing for the lifting of EU sanctions as set out in the Iran nuclear agreement. That includies restrictions on financial systems like SWIFT. "Banks that were subject to sanctions specified in the nuclear deal will automatically be able to reconnect "following the completion of our normal connection process, that is administrative and systems checks, connectivity and technical arrangements", SWIFT said.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Access for Iranian banks through SWIFT appears to be the last domino in the series which starts with Iran taking steps to comply with agreed to terms, IAEA inspections, and IAEA verification.  Iran really wants this, as do business interests, but going to 100% is more risky than I can handle.
US and Iran will want to message each other they are complying with the agreement.

Returning to my original forecast +3 points. This process for reinstatement is going smoothly with all legal and mechanistic items for reintegration of the bulk of the Iranian banking system into SWIFT in place. All that remains is the IAEA report, and for a variety of reasons, including the easily subverted collection protocol, I expect that all issues will have been resolved satisfactorily.
Upping my forecast as things seem to be going well so far, Iran wants this badly, and it's needed for trade to resume.
If not then the agreement may fall apart and that would be a big disaster
Yes, this is a very important goal for Iran and they will focus on satisfying the requirements necessary to accomplish this.
The deal is done, all sides signed off on it, it will take a tail risk event to derail it.
Yes, this is a necessary step if the goal of the Iran deal is to bring them into the fold of the international community.

Definitely.  Iran wants to become part of the western economic community.  Change in socialization comes with improved and a more flexible economy.  Iran's demographics are changing and per capita the younger population is educated. The Imam will talk smack to assuage local politics but the next generation will see real change in how Iran conducts its socio-political  business.
The nuclear deal was just a way for the West to save face to bring Iran back into the world economy. SWIFT access will be authorized before next summer.

After 40 years living in isolation, Iran and western investors are awaiting an unpredescented access to an untouched market. Its market consists of its big spender people and a bridge to central Asia and Afghanistan. Cheap labor, cheap energy, large consumer market and vast numbers of west-educated young professional are nothing but highly attractive for investors. The only risk is whether it can weather the Saudis competition.
The agreement will be implemented by the West

From somewhat support from Iran supreme leader and emergence of reformers like Rouhani and his public support and with most of world leaders supporting this deal,  sanctions will be lifted. In the end it is Obama, s policy of diplomacy first and last the use of power.

The United States is set to issue conditional sanctions waivers for Iran, though actual implementation is likely several months away, U.S. officials said Oct. 18, Reuters reported. Germany's foreign minister said in a separate statement that sanctions on Iran would likely remain in place until at least January. Officials also said the timing of nuclear-related sanctions relief will depend on the speed at which Iran takes the steps needed to enable the U.N. nuclear watchdog to confirm Tehran's compliance as required under the nuclear deal reached in Vienna.

http://www.theguardian.com/world/julian-borger-global-security-blog/2015/oct/15/iaea-completes-investigation-into-irans-nuclear-past Iran has completed it's submission of material to the IAEA regarding "past and present outstanding issues concerning it's nuclear program.  The IAEA will give a final assessment on resolution of these issues by Dec. 15.  Rouhani hopes to complete Iranian requirements for "Implementation" Day by Feb. 26, 2016.  Sounds optimistic, still, raising forecast as a result.

Thinking about this question a bit more.  Issue is exactly that which @walt describes below; the question conflates Implimentation Day with 1 August. Provided that Adoption Day occurs as soon as 16 October (as speculated in the Iranian press) that leaves 9 1/2 months for all of the residual issues to be addressed and resolved. While this appears to be a generous time frame, one must always remember that all generally does not go according to Hoyle. OTOH, there is every incentive for the Iranians to cooperate and reduce the timeline as much as practible to Implimentation Day. Even Rouhani has gone optimistic as @cmeinel has noted previously, stating that he expects the full lifting of sanctions to occur within 2 months of Adoption Day. In balance, a 9 1/2 month timeframe may sound reasonable for resolution, but I think not. There are a number of political components to achieving this resolution process, so I am going to back off the general consensus a bit and recalibrate as necessary. @walt gives it a 1 in 3 probability, I will go at 2 in 3.

Iran's moderates, led by Rouhini, have done an amazing job of greasing the skids to the lifting of sanctions. Example: ramming the nuclear deal through the Majlis without permitting debate or amendments from the floor. Hard liners are outraged, saying the vote was constitutional, but appear to be giving up without anything more than verbal tantrums. Wildcard: February 2016 elections. Black Swan alert: israel attacks Iran? In his first speech since the approval of the nuclear deal, Rouhani said that the international sanctions on Iran would be removed in two months. http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/10/iran-parliament-nuclear-deal-illegal.html
Not likely with Jason in prison and Implementation Day more like October 2016.

Maybe I'm missing something here, but my reading says that the EU allows Iran access to SWIFT as just one of many things that happen on implementation day. I don't see anywhere where SWIFT can be excepted from the list and done earlier or later. If that's the case, the question is equivalent to "will implementation day occur before 1 August." There are a lot of moving parts in making implementation day happen complicated by, as Jean-Pierre point out, the historically "glacial pace" of nuclear issues. Therefore, I'm going to be contrarian and put it at one chance in three for now.
UN panel about ready to approve sanctions removal (link disappeared into the internet pipes).

Initial forecast. Staying with the crowd at the moment, but it is highly likely that the IAEA will find the Iranians in compliance with the agreement.  As the sanction originated as a EU ruling, thankfully this should allow the decision to return access to Iranian banks to not be entangled in our currently tortured political environment. The Parchin samples are now in analysis, and it is expected that because of the sampling protocol being followed it is not likely that anything of note will be found. In any case, cleanup activity has been ongoing at that site since 2012.   The IAEA will continue to use these sampling procedures (i.e. samples are taken by the Iranians without IAEA inspectors present) at all military sites, so there is a high likelihood of compromised findings. However, it will be interesting to see if residues found at the Parchin site may finally explain the massive explosion that occurred at that facility back in October of 2014.
Iran's parliament has approved nuclear deal: 161 votes yes, 59 n0 and 13 abstentions. This one step toward  removal of restrictions.

I would hope so. Access to SWIFT was the biggest single incentive for Iran to make a deal. They will want restrictions to lifted as soon as possible. If sanctions are not lifted, Iran has the right under the JCPOA to resume whatever nuclear weapons program they may or may not have had. It's in everyone's interest to lift sanctions in a timely manner as long as Iran appears to be complying.
Decided long time frame almost certainly in favor of renewed access.
Highly probable that Iran will approve deal, SWIFT access is a key interest and August is a long ways off compared to a lot of the other milestones we're forecasting.

Source: Dateline 10-2-15 In late February 2016, Iran will see two important elections. One is for the Assembly of Experts, a constitutional body. The other is for the Majlis, Iran’s parliament. As Iran prepares for the vote, the power struggle between the hardliners and the moderates and reformists is intensifying. This showdown, even more than the discussions about the Iran deal negotiated by the P5+1, will shape Iranian politics in the years and decades to come. Foreign Affairs This Week [newsletters@e.foreignaffairs.com]

Re: the demand for marginal Iranian crude barrels: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-10/iran-gets-ready-to-sell-oil-to-the-world Notice that US companies are uninterested, whether for political reasons or b/c the oil price is low and we're close to import/export parity already anyway.   The list of Board of Directors for IAEA contains 1 US, 2 Swedes, 1 Japanese, 1 Egyptian.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency The IAEA reports informally to the Security Council, which is of course dominated by the US, and increasingly China.  China and Japan can already be sold Iranian oil even pre-sanctions, so SWIFT access for Iran doesn't change much for them.  If anything, the existing sanctions lead them to import goods for lower prices from Iran.  I think the IAEA will basically be US muppets overall since the US is dominant and the main ones that have beef w/ Iran:  "U.S. Congressional opponents have threatened to cut off IAEA funding unless they receive confidential details of the agreement that gives inspectors access to information about Parchin."  http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-08-25/iran-says-ballyhoo-over-parchin-won-t-hinder-iaea-inspection So I don't see an intense desire for the US to want to pass Iran.  But merely to upset Iran's desire for nuclear.  The simple act of doing inspections at all will allow the US to garner some intel, regardless of whether they pass Iran.  I think the US's incentive is to stall the inspection process. Re: the supply of marginal Iranian crude barrels: Iran has ramped up its production already, and the oil is already being sent to Europe or other places already.  http://iran-times.com/iran-trying-to-sell-oil-in-eu-at-discount/.   China just recently began importing Chinese barrels again after a 6-month break.  http://www.cnbc.com/2015/09/30/reuters-america-update-1-iranian-condensate-exports-at-2015-high-as-china-resumes-buying-sources.html.  This appears to represent a 15% increase in condensate exports for Iran overnight.  This reduces the incentive for Iran to have to comply w/ inspection.  If they don't even need to pass, things could easily get delayed.  I actually think Iran would like to have nuclear weapons on tap, so this desire may get them to stall the inspectors indefinitely.  They have to weigh these desires to "be their own man" (http://iran-times.com/editor-says-leader-opposes-nuke-deal/) against having to sell oil at a little discount.  Meanwhile, Europeans are probably enjoying getting those barrels at discount.  The fact that the illegally-exported barrels are now being sold through private co's and by telephone absolves the NOIC of direct responsibility. Oil is in contango and Iran owns a large number of oil shippers, so Iran's financial incentive is to keep its tankers fully loaded, serving as additional storage.  Only once the storage is maxed out would Iran want to export.  "Windward, a Tel Aviv operated maritime data and analytics company, estimated this week that Iran was storing 43.098 million barrels of crude and condensate on vessels at sea, down from 54 million barrels in early July."  http://www.cnbc.com/2015/09/30/reuters-america-update-1-iranian-condensate-exports-at-2015-high-as-china-resumes-buying-sources.html.  So that tells me there is no immediate need to get tankers unloading crude, since they can make more storing more on tankers and selling later-dated futures to hedge them. Re: Syria, I'm not sure if Russia's fresh attacks will increase or decrease the Qud's involvement, which would escalate or de-escalate tensions w/ the US on that front.  But w/ Iran verbally approving of Russia (http://en.trend.az/iran/politics/2438747.html), I don't see much de-escalation w/ the US there even if Quds aren't heavily active there. Overall, the impetus to pass inspections doesn't seem as strong as it publicly may appear.  That said, a deal was made, so presumably Iran does want to follow through w/ sanction release, unless Iran did the deal merely to entice buyers of its goods to increase purchases w/ the idea being that Iran is about to get paid more through a free market, so buyers "better act now," which would only be a temporary benefit that probably wasn't worth the trouble of going through with the deal just for that.  But Rouhani got elected on a platform promising an economic boost from negotiating sanctions, so he probably wants this done.  The main thing I'm wondering is whether the US is just playing w/ Iran.  I think they'll pass eventually, but probably not by end of July. The Tehran stock market index peaked along w/ the signing of the deal on 7/15/15.  http://new.tse.ir/en/indices.html.  Classic sell-the-news timing there.  World markets have dropped since then, and Tehran's drop isn't excessive in comparison.  But if sanctions were going to lift soon, I would expect some eventual follow-through to occur on the stock market.  Don't forget to mentally adjust the chart down ~15% on an annual basis due to inflation and currency devaluation relative to the USD.  In real terms, then, the chart looks even weaker.  The chart to date is slightly pessimistic on the sanctions occurring soon, then, in my opinion.
Iran will meet the requirements of the JCP by Jun 30, 2016  leading the EU to remove restrictions to Iran's access to SWIFT.

http://www.icis.com/resources/news/2015/09/17/9923392/iran-may-divert-up-to-20-pe-pp-volumes-from-asia-to-europe/
Iran is expected to re-join the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT) services network by the end of the year or early next year, paving the way for the resumption of petrochemical and crude trades with Europe.
Affirming. See my comment to Dwight Smith.

Anticipating delays to the timetable which, as it stands, would mean the lifting of sanctions and restrictions on access to SWIFT (i.e., Implementation Day) would take place sometime between mid-May and mid-August. Except for inspections, my experience has been that nuclear issues are never resolved quickly. For those who took part in the GJP, consider some of the nuclear-related questions that were launched in past seasons: -Japan nuclear restart: Launched season 2 (or 3) and resolved last week.
-Dabaa nuclear plant construction begins: Launched season 2 (or 3) and they're still working on it.
-Australian export of uranium to India: Launched season 1 and still in the process of happening. These questions are not exactly analogous as there was some public resistance to all three, but they do give an indication that establishing an accurate timetable to resolve nuclear issues is very difficult. Source: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/11/world/middleeast/whats-next-for-the-iran-nuclear-deal.html?_r=1
JCPA: https://s3.amazonaws.com/s3.documentcloud.org/documents/2165388/iran-deal-text.pdf Thanks to supers Mike Tarka and quaker4566 for links and analysis. (That said, their actual forecasts may be very different from mine.)

Comparison class: The speed with which Iran enabled the Parchin inspection bodes well.  Key players: Apparently, given the latest news, Iran's Parliament will not to vote on the nuclear deal, the rationale being that no other signatories to the deal are having their legislative bodies vote on it. The concept is that the deal is not a treaty, but rather an executive agreement among many nations to lift sanctions if Iran follows agreed upon actions. Wildcard: hardliners might achieve a vote in Parliament, and reject the agreement, and the Ayatollah might abide by that vote.

I gather that implementation date is the key.  It could theoretically happen as soon as 90 days after sanction removal, which I believe would be possible after implementation date.  While there could be some delays, it is clear that Iran wants SWIFT access very badly and soon.  So it seem all parties are motivated to move quickly.   Here is an interesting article offering some color on Iran's position regarding SWIFT access:
http://www.algemeiner.com/2015/07/27/iran-set-to-receive-massive-relief-from-swift-sanctions/

Yes. This will be one of first steps in normalization. Those frozen funds has to get in and out somehow.
Is delay possible? Yes.
This will be one of the first confidence building steps taken by the P5+1 and serves the purpose of opening Iran up to international markets.

There are a number of steps before SWIFT restrictions lifted including positive (for Iran) IAEA inspection (Parchin) findings /discussions.     There could be more delays than initially anticipated.   https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/statements/iaea-director-generals-remarks-press-visit-iran
Iran's parliament will not approve the CPA.
The plan is on track and there are only benefits for the Iranians at this point so what would be the purpose of them derailing it?

Movement to check off inspection of Parchin encourages me to think the agreement is on track.
Yes - Russians have shown they can circumvent swift. In everyone's best interest to leverage it rather than splintering.

http://www.cbsnews.com/news/60-minutes-interview-with-iran-president-rouhani/ President Rouhani: The enmity that existed between the United States and Iran over the decades, the distance, the disagreements, the lack of trust, will not go away soon. What’s important is which direction we are heading?  Are we heading towards amplifying the enmity or decreasing this enmity? I believe we have taken the first steps towards decreasing this enmity.

President Obama has the votes needed to get US approval of the JCPOA. There is much desire for legacy building and only a vocal minority that is out of power calling for military action. The EU will also approve the deal and really wants to sell goods to Iran. The UNSC is also on board. Iran highly desires the sanctions lift and will play ball in the short term for long term gain such as this. Odds are good at this rate.
Lowering probability in order to harmonize with my concerns that Iran's hardliners might defeat the nuclear deal.

Thinking this is a done deal for tow reasons. First, the IAEA and Iran seem to be intent on resolving their issues quickly and keeping the agreement on track. (this is based primarily on the IAEA apparently allowing Iran to take its own soil samples from Parchin.) Second, France wants to sell stuff in Iran: "A high-ranking French political and economic delegation is to visit Tehran on Sunday to pave the way for trade exchanges between the two countries."
http://iranfrontpage.com/headlines/id/4525/
The US administration must lift this as part of its nuclear deal given Congressional opposition. power play ,aside from other reasons.

The Europeans are worried about their economy and eager to begin trade and normalize relations. I would expect they would try to achieve this before the November elections in the US in case the radical groups gain control

The default seems to be that Iran will be allowed to access SWIFT on the Implementation Date.  It seems likely, but not certain, that this will happen before the question deadline.  My rescaled crowd prediction would be 62% (rescaled because the average crowd prediction is 34% rather than my base rate of 25%).  I am going to increase this a bit because I don't trust my rescaling with likely-to-happen events like this one.
Iran wants restrictions lifted and will do what is necessary.
Inception date of Iran agreement likely to be around April - 4 months seems reasonable given that banking infrastructure will likely be one of first
unless some odd circumstances occur within or in the vicinity of Iran

Iran wants the deal and access to funds and sales of oil and lifting of sanctions. Obama wants this deal finalized and moved off the table. Other negotiating partners have signed off on deal (essentially). IF SWIFT sanctions would remain very long, this will become a problem for the 2016 election.
Yes, only a question of timing (assuming nuclear deal stays in place). Only question is timing.

U.S. and the international community are willing to continue diplomatic relationships with Iran and avoid further sanctions/restrictions. They don't want a dangerous Iran that can easily turn back to Russia and Syria and create further danger to the zone and threats to the rest of the world.

The quest is really asking: How long will it take for IAEA to verify compliance with the plan of action? Verification can begin on September 18th 2015, and would need to be completed in about 45 weeks. This seems reasonable. However, the Iranians have added a minimum 80 day discussion period, which could push the starting date back to at least October 2nd if the we assume it started on the signing date. The pressure on Iran is such that, at least in the short term, they will mostly likely comply with the JCPOA as quickly as possible. It seems reasonable that inspections could be completed in 3 months, and analysis in another 4-6.

Iran has been relying upon a system of couriers for quite some time to avoid sanctions. Conflicts in Syrian and Turkish border areas have made that activity much more difficult, and the decline in gold prices has limited the effectiveness of couriers. A return to SWIFT access is essential to restart business activities in Iran, especially those with western oil companies. SWIFT also affects Iranian shipping and ship insurance cover, which have been restricted under sanctions.

"Iran says it has not yet decided how to reduce its enriched uranium stockpile — which it must do under the July 14 nuclear deal it signed with six world powers."  https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/iran-still-pondering-what-to-do-with-excess-uranium/2015/09/10/ba761582-57c1-11e5-9f54-1ea23f6e02f3_story.html Implementation Day will likely have set backs. Most, like this one, will go without much reporting. Iran and IAEA agreeing on times, methods and actual inspectors could also drag. It will eventually all get done, probably.  A few months beyond estimates may not matter much to Iran. Getting inspections and stockpile deals to Tehran’s liking may be worth the time. Going on 5 years at GJP/I, I don't recall much getting done on schedule.  Something this complicated, it's likely to have hiccups.

Don't get confused JCPA implementation does not equal immediate SWIFT access.  They are "not the same thing".
Remember individual sanctions are; so easy to impose, so complicated to lift.
Don't get overly optimistic this is happening quickly, the devil is in the details.
One thing for certain , not going to be happening as some sudden wildcard event.  The lifting will be decided behind the scenes but media will be exploited to test the public reaction in advance.  So follow the media story and political test balloons and adjust.

The legal firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP estimates Implementation Day may come as early as Jan / Feb of next year but does caution "it could also take much
longer." Fairly reasonable to expect that Iran will find it in its best interests to get the deal consummated as soon as possible.
I expect the IAEA to make them jump thru hoops and so an  Implementation Date  in the first half of 2016 is a little optimistic.  I think  it could take a year.

Zarif hit a home run in his testimony before Iran's special committee of its Parliament, formed specifically to vet the nuclear deal. The body language -- a hug --between him and leading anti-nuclear deal MP Mehdi Bazrpash speaks more than words. The nuclear deal will be approved. The remaining uncertainty is the usual Murphy's Law consideration. Source: Dateline 9-14-15 In a lighter moment, after the testimony, Zarif and member of parliament Mehdi Bazrpash, who also is the editor of hard-line Vatan-e-Emrooz, hugged one another. Bazrpash had a number of heated exchanges with Zarif during his testimony, and Bazrpash's paper has been one of the staunchest opponents of the nuclear deal.
 http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/09/zarif-jcpoa-parliament-committee.html
Foreign banks want Iran in. Iran wants acceptability.

The deal looks overwhelming likely to be approved, and get back into SWIFT is high priority for the Iranians.
SWIFT access looks likely for the spring. http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/iran-aims-to-rejoin-swift/2005714.html
Once the JCPA is implemented, Iran will be given access to SWIFT since this would be the initial step in removing embargoes on Iranian finances and commerce.
Congressional support and international support looks to be behind implementing the deal.

Agree w/ pretty much everyone else. One additional factor is that Europe will really want this to happen. they have a much more significant history of selling industrial goods and services to Iran, and SWIFT access makes that easier.
This is all part of making iran a part of the world community
Unless everything breaks down pretty fast, this should happen in the next 4-6 months at the latest.

This is probably the first financial restriction Iran will want lifted, even more than the return of its own money currently frozen overseas. Iran will do everything needed to expedite this. From what I can make out, the earliest this can happen is six months from late October, so there are a further three months to deal with hitches along the way. Unless there are serious and unexpected disagreements between the parties as to interpretation of some clauses of the Agreement, this is almost certain.
I need to read more about this, but isn't the lifting of these restrictions at the top of Iran's wishlist?

Backing off a bit, given that "Implementation Day" when SWIFT will readmit Iranian banks is not totally under Iranian control. However, the news story below indicated it should not take longer than nine months. Given the importance to Iran, to the extent that Iran can control the timeline, it should be sooner. Source: Dateline 9-10-15 Nobody knows for sure when that [Implementation Day] may be. American experts say it will take six to nine months for Iran to carry out the initial nuclear steps that are required for the accord to take effect. Iran insists it can act more quickly.  http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/11/world/middleeast/whats-next-for-the-iran-nuclear-deal.html

The Iran nuclear deal going through implies SWIFT reintegration to high likelihood. Currently Iran and North Korea are the only nations banned from SWIFT. So it beggars belief to imagine that SWIFT sanctions would remain against Iran as soon as the new nuclear deal is finalized. Wildcard: Iranian hardliners succeed in scuttling the deal. I will raise probability as soon as that hurdle is past.

In order for the Iranian economy to fully reintegrate, they must have SWIFT access. If they are cooperative then it will happen within this timeframe. It is to everyone's advantage that the Iranians reintegrate except for the Iranian leadership. Once sanctions are lifted and the economy begins to improve there will be no one but the government to blame if the lives of average Iranians does not improve. I wonder if Tehran has considered this as an unintended consequence of the deal?

Definitely an integral part of the deal. 
"SWIFT is putting the onus on the EU to assume the burden of the decision of whether Iran will be reintegrated into its system. So, upon “Implementation Day” — when the International Atomic Energy Agency verifies that Iran has fulfilled the implementation of specified nuclear measures — the EU will be obliged to order SWIFT to readmit Iran’s banks."
http://foreignpolicy.com/2015/07/17/it-just-got-easier-for-iran-to-fund-terrorism-swift-bank/
Implementation day should be in 1H of 2016: http://www.ecfr.eu/article/iran_explainer3070

Low forecast to start. There are numerous provisions that Iran will need to meet, and it seems likely that every possible violation of the requirements will be thoroughly investigated, delays should be expected. Iran will work to remove sanctions as quickly as possible, but all of the deals opponents will make the final removal of sanctions as complicated as possible. Time line from "More Info Sources::
Adoption Day: "the terms of the agreement will not come into effect until three months after the UNSC endorses the accord.
.... ‘Adoption Day’ (may) will take place in late October (2015). Implementation Day: "Iran must make available to the IAEA information about ‘past and present issues’ related to its nuclear activity. It should also complete several key measures to limit its nuclear programme.  Previous statements by nuclear experts have suggested that it will probably take Iran at least six months to complete these steps, and an additional one to two months for the IAEA to verify Iranian actions. At the same time, the EU and the US will adopt resolutions and issue waivers on all nuclear-related sanctions. The EU document suggests that these should take effect on ‘Implementation Day’, which is when the IAEA has verified Iranian compliance." (end of April 2016 to end of June 2016). The EU is due to remove the SWIFT sanctions on implementation day, provided all required processes, including re-certification of Iranian banks, which will need to re-apply for SWIFT access.

Lawfare article gives the list of what Iran and IAEA have to do before this sanction gets lifted. A May-June 2016 timeframe for sanctions relief will probably be optimistic.  https://www.lawfareblog.com/comprehensive-timeline-iran-deal Once ‘Implementation Day’  happens, SWIFT won't waste time.  http://news.riskadvisory.net/2015/16/iran-summary-of-nuclear-deal-timeline-and-sanctions-relief/  The push of wanting sanctions relief meets the pull of Iran still being Iran.
